body: @drcrallen sure, i can give that a try

https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3222 is labeled 0.9.2, I'd like more understanding of why we're getting library version conflicts before that is merged. This is part of that understanding. If #3222 is part of 0.9.2 then I think this needs to be either resolved or accepted as part of that overall solution
üëç after docs updated.
@hamlet-lee any chance of finishing this up based on @drcrallen's comment? I agree that generating unique intermediate paths will be nice
I think it's hadoop-aws pulling in jackson, most of the distros include that.

i.e. the actual hadoop machines have com.fasterxml.jackson stuff on their classpath. I think their databind replaces the one Druid wants, but then Druid adds in the jackson guava module, which doesn't work with the databind provided by the hadoop machine. (and that's also why setting user classpath first helps)

That's my story and I'm sticking to it :)

@gianm that sounds like a reasonable theory. In such a case the proper solution is for hadoop to not pollute the application classloader with extension jars. But, if `mapreduce.job.user.classpath.pollute=false` doesn't work then `mapreduce.job.user.classpath.first=true` is about the best alternative.

If hadoop-aws indeed turns out to be the culprit, then we should file an issue against https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HADOOP re: conflicting jackson classes caused by hadoop-aws. Related to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HADOOP-12705 and https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HADOOP-11074

and I had to add that directory to the classpath on the hadoop side to use S3 successfully.

@drewdahlke would you help to try this newest fix?
This is important.

Daniel Lemire, Gregory Ssi-Yan-Kai, Owen Kaser, Consistently faster and smaller compressed bitmaps with Roaring, Software: Practice and Experience, 2016. 
http://arxiv.org/abs/1603.06549
üëç
LGTM, üëç , would be nice to make RLE enable by default in case it does not have any significant overheads.
@rajk-tetration TimeBoundaryQuery.getCacheKey needs to be updated too.

@gianm 

No, there should be no significant downside to activating run compression. In theory, there is a tiny overhead during serialization, but it is small, and often more than compensated by storage savings so that the end result is faster overall serialization. In the worst case, run compression brings little storage benefit and slightly lower performance, but there should be many cases where you have a large net win. We recommend it as the default.

As for compatibility problems...   I think that what you are saying is correct...

> RLE containers are not readable by pre 0.5 versions of roaring.

... but I am not sure there is a problem.

Roaring is backward compatible. So the library will happily load bitmaps without run compression. The older versions of the library will balk at bitmaps with run compression, but then why would it ever have to read them? It would only be a problem if someone upgraded Druid, rewrote the indexes, and then downgraded Druid... then you'd get (clean) exceptions (something about an unrecognized cookie).

If this ever happened and you wanted to make you index "go back in time", that is, undo the added compression, the Roaring API got you covered if you ever want to support this... https://github.com/RoaringBitmap/RoaringBitmap/blob/master/src/main/java/org/roaringbitmap/buffer/MutableRoaringBitmap.java#L1194

Please note that Roaring uses header cookies. This comes at a tiny cost storage-wise, but it has the benefit that the Roaring bitmaps are "self described". It limits the risk regarding data corruption. That is, you don't get Roaring trying to load and interpret garbage... instead, it balks after reading one word and throws up an exception which you can quickly interpret.
@gianm I'm not really sure what `getCacheKey` is, is it just a unique identifier for this query? Should I serialize the filter and add it to the buffer?

> It would only be a problem if someone upgraded Druid, rewrote the indexes, and then downgraded Druid...

Yeah, that's the case I was thinking of. It can happen when someone updates a cluster, decides something about it isn't working for them after a few days, and rolls it back. Maybe that's fine though, we could point this out in the release notes and anyone concerned about that could set the property to false until they're confident they won't need to roll back.

I'm OK with setting the default to "true" and including something in the release notes. Anyone care to chime in on that plan?

@ecesena, can you add the comment the @gianm mentioned about hadoop coordinates ? 
I think its pretty close to be merged.

@gianm üëç  We only officially support version-to-version upgrades, not jumping around. So as long as a rollback can occur between, say, 0.9.2 and 0.9.1, I think its OK. Anyone expecting to roll back to 0.8.1 from 0.9.2 has other problems.
@fjy @nishantmonu51 @drcrallen @lemire I changed the default to true and updated the docs

@mdeora this extension is a community extension, which are not included in the tarball by default.

http://druid.io/docs/0.9.1.1/development/extensions.html

@drcrallen IMHO,  i agree with @navis about restricting the characters in dimension name to not have funky things like '/' and ',' etc. It sounds reasonable to me.
If we allow them now then it will be very difficult later to enforce any rules because of the historical data present in the clusters.
Since there is some disagreement on how to handle this, I've removed the milestone and added Discuss flag

Maybe this is the right time to define an `isValidColumnName` function.

If we did that, then when dimensionless indexing schemas is used, fields with invalid column names could be ignored (probably with a warning the first time a field is seen). At least then the behavior would be nicer than just crashing. Personally I tend to want to be lenient on this kind of thing so I think `/` is a reasonable character to include in a column name. IMO most characters other than control characters should be fine, and probably anything up to 255 bytes when utf8 encoded.

Update: I looked into this code again as we are exploring the option to only start hadoop for our nightly reindex task. One problem I'm running into now is that we already have a lot of segments with a hdfs LoadSpec. We would need to someone convert these to a google load spec. Or we need to somehow have this google storage plugin also handle the hdfs spec segments. I looked into this but I'm not familiar with how these specs are bound to their type and if this can be overwritten for example. Anyone have any suggestions of this is possible? Otherwise is converting all the payloads in mysql and all the descriptor.json files enough to change the load specs?
Agreed

Part of this is why `startupLoggingConfig.isLogProperties` exists. You can turn it off to prevent it here.

but it will STILL print it out as part of running an indexing task.
See https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2464 and https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2452 for related items

hah, didn't realize there's already a long discussion on this like #2452 . I'd very much like and want logging properties on start, but for sensitive data (url, name, passwd , etc), they should either be masked or don't print it at all. thx @drcrallen
updated based on the review comments

squashed commits to ease rebase. 
@fjy no spectial handling, but I think Long.valueOf(String) and Double.valueOf(String) has some difference on cost.
0.9.1 was rolled out about Jun23, many weeks before this error was encountered. I do not think it is a regression.
Is this always from the same segment or is it from different segments? I wonder if one particular segment was corrupted before being uploaded, and now can't be loaded.
@gianm investigating still

There's actually 3 segments, the first of which appeared on 2016-07-05. It is unclear why these became corrupted, or why we've seen more of the corruption recently. Checking to see if they come from the same hardware.
Thanks @gianm  I will try to work around by adding  "" to dimensionExclusions, and tell you if it works.

@himanshug documenting the caveat seems fine. 
Also, How do you feel about just doing task announcement in a multi threaded exec instead of making complete runPendingTasks method multithreaded ?
other tasks for selecting a task to assign and mapping it to worker can still be done in a single thread (We are anyways adding sync blocks for it).

I believe that might make the code simpler and easy to understand.
We may even be able to abstract out the logic for task announcement in a separate MultithreadedTaskAnnouncer class.

I'm working on getting this rolled out internally

@birdspring, the intent with the Imply packaging is that you would start just one supervisor per machine. If you want to run master and data services on the same machine, you could combine them into a single supervisor config (see http://imply.io/docs/latest/operations.html). Or you could use the bundled quickstart.conf, which starts all services (master, data, and query).

Also, this repo is for Druid itself; you can file Imply distribution specific issues here in the future: https://github.com/implydata/distribution

Results are promising so far. With this patch tending to lead to ~50% reduction in old-gen (java heap%) size as time progresses. Orange is this patch, Blue is a node without this patch. Both were restarted at nearly the same time (as close as rolling-restarts can get you)

@jon-wei is the master comment's benchmark data up-to-date? I see a lot of other benchmark info in the comment thread
Why does the broker need both? Shouldn't it only have a `FilteredServerInventoryView`?
@himanshug  / @nishantmonu51 ^^^^?

It looks like the one place it asks for injection of a `ServerInventoryView` instead of `FilteredServerInventoryView` is DruidBroker.java. Switching that to a FilteredServerInventoryView should work too and seems like a cleaner solution.
@gianm I'd like to get https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3238 anyways so the space that replicants of a segment take up are minimized

Per https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3237#issuecomment-232425351 it seems fair to do this in order to de-dupe replicas of the same segment regardless of what happens for #3237.

For #3237 IMO this shouldn't be considered a fix, we should actually collapse the two server views into one.
@gianm agreed on not a fix. I'm hoping "Related" doesn't count as "Fixed" in github-land-auto-closing
üëç
@himanshug gotcha, my visual inspection was putting the `}` in the wrong place

agree with @gianm DruidBroker needs to be fixed to use FilteredServerInventoryView
will submit a fix shorty.

On https://hadoop.apache.org/docs/r2.7.1/hadoop-mapreduce-client/hadoop-mapreduce-client-core/mapred-default.xml I see a property mapreduce.job.classloader, defaults to false, that might be a nicer way of dealing with this. I suggest the following:
- no matter what, we should update guice
- we should document mapreduce.job.classloader = true as a good default setting for druid jobs, assuming it actually solves the problems
- if mapreduce.job.classloader = true doesn't solve the problems, we should document mapreduce.job.user.classpath.first = true as a workaround that people can use if they run into problems with guice/jackson/guava whatever

And after doing that we should also look into updating Jackson :) [in a separate PR]

@gianm Looks like that setting has been around since at least [2.4.1](http://hadoop.apache.org/docs/r2.4.1/hadoop-mapreduce-client/hadoop-mapreduce-client-core/mapred-default.xml).

@jon-wei is it reasonable to test if `mapreduce.job.classloader=true` fixes things at least as well as `mapreduce.job.user.classpath.first=true`?
If so then I think @gianm 's comments in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3222#issuecomment-232446052 are the best approach we have right now.
These should be documented in aggregations.md.
@drcrallen It's not, the later ones are in the comments. I'll re-run benchmarks and update the master comment after addressing @gianm's latest comment.
I think this won't work at indexing time as-is; we would need a serde for writing out columns that have the (timestamp, last value) pairs in them.

@drcrallen @gianm 

Ran this again with `mapreduce.job.classloader=true` and without the `mapreduce.job.user.classpath.first` setting.

SequenceIQ 2.6.0, 2.7.1 succeeds

Cloudera Quickstart succeeds

Hortonworks Sandbox 2.4 succeeds

EMR 4.7.1 succeeds

---

Looks like `mapreduce.job.classloader=true` works for Hadoop versions 2.6.0+.

Running now with both `mapreduce.job.classloader=true` and `mapreduce.job.user.classpath.first=true`...
@jon-wei those are odd, makes me think SequenceIQ did something weird to Hadoop classloading. Especially since Hortonworks 2.4 works
@drcrallen HortonWorks 2.4 is based on hadoop 2.7.1, I believe
ah, I see

Based on those I'm pretty happy with recommending `mapreduce.job.classpath=true` by default, and suggesting that on older hadoops you might need `mapreduce.job.user.classpath.first`.

If that sounds good then I will update the docs on this PR.

@gianm I just got some results from running with both `mapreduce.job.classloader=true` and `mapreduce.job.user.classpath.first=true`.

Having `mapreduce.job.classloader=true` still causes failures (same kind as before) on the < 2.6.0 versions I tried, so the user will probably have to set `mapreduce.job.classloader=false` and `mapreduce.job.user.classpath.first=true` for those older versions.
Going to re-run benchmarks now.
@drcrallen @gianm  updated benchmarks in original comment
